_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: All dead legs were identified in the spill prevention plan and are being worked through LRP.  Removed all high risk dead legs. Tk6401 water draining was included and updated in winterization plan.
Added pump seal pot pressure alarm

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Phillips 66 - East St Louis Terminal is a refined petroleum product distributor.  The East St Louis Terminal is an on-shore, light products, bulk petroleum storage facility used in the storage and distribution of petroleum products to retail or commercial end-users.  The Terminal handles and stores various grades of unleaded gasoline, transmix, diesel fuel, jet fuel, butane, propane, and various other petroleum-based additives. 

This Risk Management Program (RMP) covers the Dehydrator Regeneration (Butane) and Propane Truck Loading Process and Butane Blending Process at the Terminal (herein also referred to as "the Facility").  This document complies with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Accidental Release Prevention Provisions (40 CFR Part 68) and includes by reference the Process Safety Management Program elements in 29 CFR Part 1910.119. The process is classified as Program Level 3 under the EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) regulation.  

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES:
The primary function of the Facility is to act as a refined petroleum storage and distribution facility.  By virtue of the flammable effects associated with liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), it is necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling Butane and Propane to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to employee health, and to minimize the threat and impact to nearby members of the community.  Phillips 66 - East St Louis Terminal is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety and health.  Safety at the Facility depends upon the manner in which LPG are handled as well as the various safety devices incorporated into the design of the process.  Furthermore, comprehensive training is provided to employees and contractors, which reinforces the safety policies and procedures of the Facility.

In addition to the presence of appropriate controls to prevent or minimize possible releases of Butane and Propan

e, if a release does occur, an emergency response plan is in place for the Facility and response activities are coordinated with the local fire department, St. Clair County Local Emergency Planning Committee, and Illinois Division of Emergency Services to control and mitigate the effects of the release.

THE REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED AT THE FACILITY:
The RMP regulated substance handled at the distribution facility is Butane and Propane.  The maximum amount of Butane that can be stored at this facility is approximately 660,000 pounds. The maximum amount of Propane that can be stored at this facility is approximately 160,000 pounds.

Propane is pumped from eight onsite DOT covered storage tanks to the truck loading dock. Through two lines, the propane passes through a filter and is loaded to a truck via hose connection. 

Butane is pumped from a Butane Tank, sent through a heater, and passes through two dehydrator towers for purpose of regeneration. The Butane is cooled and sent to a Surge Tank to separate the water before being recycled back to the dehydration process.

The Butane blending system consists of a single offload station, two butane vessels (60,000 gallons), butane supply pump and injection skid to blend butane prior to the facility gasoline truck rack.  Additional ancillary sampling system (gasoline and ethanol) is used to determine blending rate.

HAZARD ASSESSMENT RESULTS
The objectives of this hazard assessment are twofold: (1) satisfy the requirements of the RMP regulation and (2) provide Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA) information that will help local emergency planning officials improve community emergency response in the event of an accidental release at the site. Due to the nature of covered substances (propane, butane), OCA focused on potential releases of flammable materials. In modeling flammable materials, the stationary source is required to present distances to endpoints resulting from any of the following: 
	Explosion: Overpressure

of 1 Psig 
	Radiant Heat/Fire: Radiant heat of 5 kW/m2 for 40 seconds. 
	Lower Flammability Limit: a lower flammability limit as provided in NFPA documents or other generally recognized sources. 
The facility has submitted to the EPA a worst case and alternative release scenario for the regulated substance held in the covered process. The facility has modeled alternative release scenarios (ARSs) to show release scenarios that may have a more realistic chance of occurrence. Even the ARSs are rare events. The details of the process release conditions assumed for the hazard scenarios and assumptions made are provided in the Worst and Alternative Case Release Scenarios sections of the 2022 RMP Resubmission. 
Since no changes in inventory of the regulated substance or the operating conditions of the covered process have occurred in the last 5 years, the facility revalidated the Worst-Case and Alternate Scenarios that were modeled for the 2017 submission. 

THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:
Phillips 66's accidental release prevention programs and emergency planning and response programs help effectively manage the hazards posed by the facility's regulated substance to employees, contractors, the public, and the environment. The covered process is regulated by the EPA RMP regulation 40 CFR Part 68 and the OSHA Process Safety Management Standard 29CFR 1910.119. Due to that fact, the accident prevention and risk management plan is organized to be consistent with the PSM regulation requirements. The following accident prevention programs are in place at the Phillips 66 Mount Vernon Terminal: 
1.	Employee Participation, 
2.	Process Safety Information, 
3.	Process Hazard Analysis (PHA), 
4.	Standard Operating Procedures,
5.	Operator Training, 
6.	Contractors, 
7.	Pre-startup Safety Review, 
8.	Mechanical Integrity,
9.	Hazardous Work Authorization (Hot Work, etc.), 
10.	Management of Change,
11.	Incident Investigation, 
12.	Em

ergency Procedures/Planning, 
13.	Compliance Audits, and 
14.	Trade Secrets

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:
There have been no reportable accidents/incidents related to or the operation of the covered system that has caused deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place during the past five years.

THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:
Response actions are coordinated with the St. Clair County LEPC, Illinois Division of Emergency Services, and the local police and fire departments. The Facility has a written Emergency Response Program in the event of an accidental release which includes emergency health care and steps to inform the public.  A plan is in place to inform employees what to do in case of a release, fire, medical emergency, etc., and to notify emergency responders when there is a need for a response. 
As a responsible owner operator of a stationary source, in compliance with 68.210(b), the terminal will hold a public meeting to provide information required under §68.42(b), no later than 90 days after any RMP reportable accident at the stationary source with any known offsite impact specified in §68.42(a) (i.e., known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage). The terminal also holds annual meeting and communication with the county LEPC

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:
The Facility is constantly re-evaluating the current safety systems through the use of prevention programs such as Management of Change and the Process Hazard Analysis program. As a result of these programs, and other safety and risk reduction initiatives, improvements to the safety of the workers and the surrounding community continue to occur. All hazardous consequence mitigation recommendations from PHAs relating to safety and environment are prioritized by a risk matrix designed to address highest risk scenarios first.  
Since the last RMP submission one PHAs revalidation have been conducted t

o improved process safety using LOPA for assessing high consequence scenarios. PHA/LOPA recommendations are tracked and completed in a timely manner. In 2020, a new Independent Protection Layer (IPL) was added to the Butane Blending process to prevent loss a primary containment due to pump seal failures.
